messageBody:
Erik,

One way to test code that depends on random numbers is to pass the random
number generator into the object to be tested. For testing purposes, pass in
a stub generator that always produces the same sequence of numbers. For
purposes of your tests, the code will be deterministic even though in
production it isn't.

The other way I know of is to run the code multiple times and analyze the
results statistically. I much prefer the stub solution.

Take care,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

> Subject: [junit] random testing with JUnit
>
> Hi, I'm new to JUnit. I'm wondering what is the right way to set up
> some random tests?
>
> Should I just put into my tests a loop runs the test multiple times?
> This seems to imply that the test needs to call setUp() to get some
> fresh objects ("test fixture") each time through the loop,
> which seems
> somehow wrong (at least I've seen no examples like this). Is there
> some better way to ask for a test to be run N times?
>
> I got turned on to JUnit from the book
> Building Parsers with JavaT by Steven John Metsker
> however it seems that he does not use JUnit for random tests. He has
> a section extolling JUnit, but then a section immediately after about
> random testing that doesn't use JUnit at all.
>
> Perhaps random testing is not considered part of unit
> testing? If so,
> why?
>
> Thanks for the help.
> --Erik N
